definitions.definition: to move slowly on water or in the air

examples.text: A group of swans floated by.
The smell of new bread floated up from the kitchen.
Beautiful music came floating out of the window.
The boats were floating gently down the river.
Add the gnocchi and cook until they float to the surface.
People seem to float in and out of my life.
A few small clouds floated across the sky.
Her voice seemed to float on the water as gently as a slight mist.
In the dream my feet leave the ground and I start to float upwards.
An idea suddenly floated into my mind.

definitions.definition: to stay on or near the surface of a liquid and not sink

examples.text: Wood floats.
Much of the bay is covered by floating sea ice.
She relaxed, floating gently in the water.
A plastic bag was floating on the water.
We tried to make a raft but it wouldn't float.
Vast masses of frogspawn floated just beneath the surface.

definitions.definition: to make something move on or near the surface of a liquid

examples.text: There wasn't enough water to float the ship.
They float the logs down the river to the towns.

definitions.definition: to walk or move in a smooth and easy way

examples.text: She floated down the steps to greet us.
The couple floated across the dance floor.

definitions.definition: to suggest an idea or a plan for other people to consider

examples.text: They **floated the idea** of increased taxes on alcohol.

definitions.definition: to sell shares in a company or business to the public for the first time

examples.text: The company was floated on the stock market last week.
Shares were floated at 585p.

definitions.definition: if a government floats its country’s money or allows it to float, it allows its value to change freely according to the value of the money of other countries

examples.text: The government decided to allow the peso to float freely.
You can listen to whatever kind of music floats your boat.
Most couples feel they are walking on air on their wedding day.

wordOrigin: Old English flotian (verb), of Germanic origin and related to fleet ‘move or pass quickly’, reinforced in Middle English by Old French floter, also from Germanic.
